awd_titl_txt: Studying Planet Formation by Mapping Small-scale Structures in Circumstellar Disks
awd_abstract_narration:
Planets formed from material in disks that once surrounded the stars they orbit.  Part of this process includes this material clumping into larger grains or pieces.  With the new Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) and Jansky Very Large Array (VLA) radio telescopes, it is now possible to see material well into the zones in many of these disks where planets are forming.   In this project, the investigators will look first for clumps of dust of different sizes and structures in disks around other stars.  They will then study how the different structures affect the distribution of dust pieces having different sizes.  Finally, they will measure how the dust pieces are spread in the disk with respect to gases of different molecules.  The goal of this project is to learn whether the different observed structures trap solid dust pieces.   This project serves the national interest by advancing our understanding of the science behind the formation of planetary systems.  A postdoctoral scholar and a graduate student will conduct the research.  All of the raw and processed data will be available to the scientific community.

This project will study the formation of planets by mapping small-scale structures in nearby circumstellar disks around pre-main sequence stars, using ALMA and VLA radio observations that will resolve material well into the planet-forming zones of a large sample of disks.  The research has three main goals.  First, quantify the prevalence and morphology of small-scale structures in the distribution of dust particles. This will be achieved by mapping the 1.3 mm dust continuum emission in 20 nearby disks at an angular resolution of about 0.04".  Second, study how these structures affect the distribution of dust grains with different sizes.  To do this, multi-wavelength observations between 0.87 mm and 1 cm, which probe the distribution of mm- and cm-sized dust grains, will be acquired.  Third, measure the distribution of dust particles relative to the molecular gas.  This goal will be achieved by mapping the molecular line emission (e.g., CO) from disks characterized by substructures at an angular resolution comparable to that of the continuum maps.  The goal is to understand if the observed structures trap solid dust particles, therefore solving the long-standing radial migration problem.  A postdoctoral scholar and a graduate student will conduct the data analysis and publication of the results.  Additionally, the scientific community will receive access to the full suite of data products derived from this program.

por.por_cntn:
Planets are ubiquitous in our Galaxy but the physical processes responsible for their formation are poorly understood. The currently accepted theory is that planets form around newborn stars through the agglomeration of small solid particles into larger and large bodies. An alternative formation scenario predicts instead that planets might form out of the gravitational collapse of a massive circumstellar disk. Astronomers have worked on these theories and on their many pitfalls for decades, although without much useful guidance from observations.   

The main goal of this project was to investigate and constrain the physical processes that drive the formation of planets by exploiting astronomical observations capable of imaging planetary systems in the act of forming at a resolution of a few astronomical units (1 astronomical unit is the average distance between the Sun and the Earth and it correspond to about 150,000,000 km). The research activities performed under this award aimed at addressing the following three main questions: 1. Can astronomical observations witness the formation of planets, and, in doing so, inform how planets form? 2. Can astronomical observations reveal how the formation of planets affects the evolution of circumstellar material? 3. Can astronomical observations of newborn planetary systems explain the vast diversity in the architecture of the planetary systems observed around mature stars? 

As part of this award, we have obtained tens of hours of observational data using mostly the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA).  These observations pushed the capabilities of existing telescopes and transformed our understanding of planet formation. The results of this award were published in 16 articles in refereed journals and were featured in several press releases that captured the attention of the general public. As an example of the main scientific outcomes of this project, we attach to this report three images. 

The first image, "Planetary systems in formation observed by the ALMA/DSHARP project", shows a gallery of 20 images of planetary systems in the act of forming obtained as part of the ALMA large program "Disk Substructures at High Angular Resolution Project", or DSHARP. This project revealed that the vast majority of disks around young stars are characterized by annular structures in the distribution of dust particles (i.e., the building blocks of planets). On one side, these structures reveal that these systems are probably perturbed by newborn planets located in the dark regions between bright dust rings. On the other, these observations revealed for the first time that dust particles can be trapped and concentrated in annular structures, possibly leading to the formation of additional planets. Additionally, the discovery of annular structures capable of trapping dust particles solved a 5-decade long conundrum related to the fast radial drift of solid particles in circumstellar disks. 

The second image, "High resolution image of the HD163296 planet-forming disk", provides a view at an unprecedented angular resolution of one of the most interesting planet-forming disks located in the Solar neighborhood. In addition to annular structures, ALMA observations reveal the presence of arcs which are interpreted as the direct result of the tidal interaction with planets with a mass comparable to that of Saturn. In particular, very close to the center of the system, the observations suggest the existence of a planet very similar to Jupiter. Based on these results, in the summer of 2022, we will perform a direct search of planets in the HD163296 systems using the James Webb Space Telescope. 

The third image, "the PDS70 planetary system", shows the first-ever detection of a circumplanetary disk. Circumplanetary disks are disks of gas and dust that were predicted to surround newborn planets and serve as the place for the formation of moons, as in the case of Jupiter's Galilean moons. However, because circumplanetary disks are very small and only last for a few million years, they were never observed. Exploiting the exquisite sensitivity and angular resolution of ALMA, we detected emission from a disk of material surrounding the young planet PDS 70 c. With an estimated mass of about 5 times that of Jupiter, an age of a few million years, and an orbital radius of about 30 au, PDS 70 c provides a unique laboratory to study the formation of giant planets and our observations provide key information on the role that circumplanetary disks play in this process.

In addition to these important scientific results, several students and early-career scientists were trained as part of this award. One Rice graduate student developed his Ph.D. thesis project on the analysis of ALMA observations and several undergraduate students were involved in the data analysis as part of summer and graduate thesis projects. The results of this project were also presented in several public lectures during Rice observatory open houses and invited lectures at monthly meetings of amateur astronomical societies in the Houston area.
